Award.AwardTitle: TEXAS ANALYSIS AND MATHEMATICAL PHYSICS SYMPOSIUM
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for the 2015 Texas Analysis and Mathematical Physics Symposium that will take place at the University of Texas at Dallas during the Fall 2015 semester. The Texas Analysis and Mathematical Physics Symposium is a regional weekend meeting held annually, hosted in turn by Rice University, the University of Texas at Austin, and the University of Texas at Dallas. It is intended for the participation of around 60 people, including 25 non-local graduate students. The workshop brings together many senior mathematicians from Texas and neighboring states, who may not otherwise have an opportunity to discuss mathematics together throughout the year. Structurally the symposium consists of 7-8 main lectures given by nationally recognized leaders in the field, and contributed sessions, including a poster session, for advanced graduate students and participating researchers from regional universities, to present their work. This will provide graduate students with an opportunity to obtain feedback from senior faculty from other departments. The networking activities made possible by the Symposium will prove to be a valuable experience for young researchers. The Symposium encourages and financially supports participation by students, recent Ph.D. recipients, and members of groups underrepresented in mathematics. The Symposium is a forum for regional specialists in mathematical physics and related areas of analysis to become familiar with the latest problems and present their own results; in addition it introduces young mathematicians to the current state of the subject.

This year's Symposium will focus on the areas where probability theory, dynamical systems theory, spectral theory, and partial differential equations intersect and interact. More information, including a list of speakers and abstracts, registration information, and an archive of the past symposium can be found at the website of the meeting:
https://www.ma.utexas.edu/users/tc/TeXAMP/TeXAMP-2015/TeXAMP-2015.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided support for the 2015 Texas Analysis and Mathematical Physics Symposium that took place at the Department of Mathematical Sciences of the University of Texas at Dallas, Texas on November 6-8, 2015. The Texas Analysis and Mathematical Physics Symposium is a regional weekend meeting held annually. It is  hosted in turn by Rice University, the University of Texas at Austin, and occasionally other institutions in the region. The symposium is a forum for regional specialists in analysis  and mathematical physics and related areas  to become familiar with the latest problems and present their own results. It also connects  young mathematicians to the current state of the subject. It is intended for the participation of around 60 people, including 25  graduate students. This workshop, the third in row,  brought together many senior mathematicians from Texas and neighboring states, who may  otherwise have no opportunity to discuss mathematics together throughout the year. The symposium was structured to consist of 7 main lectures given by nationally recognized leaders in the field, three  parallel contributed sessions with 15 talks  and a poster session with 14 posters.   

The 7 main lectures were:  Anthony Bloch (University of Michigan) "Toda flows, gradient flows and the generalized Flaschka map"; Jon Chaika (University of Utah) "On "circle" averages on translation surfaces"; Ivan Corwin (Clay Mathematics Institute, Columbia University) "Integrable probability and the KPZ universality class"; Boris Khesin (University of Toronto) "Pentagram maps and nondegenerate curves"; Kay Kirkpartick (UIUC) "Bose-Einstein condensation: From many quantum particles to a quantum "superparticle"; Houman Owhadi (Caltech) "Computational Information Games";  Jeremy Quastel (University of Toronto) "The Kardar-Parisi-Zhang equation and universality class".   

The contributed talks and the poster session provided platforms for advanced graduate students and participating researchers from regional universities, to present their work. This  created  an opportunity for graduate students  to obtain feedback from senior faculty from other departments. The networking activities through the symposium  were an important experience for young researchers. The symposium encouraged and financially supported participation by students, recent Ph.D. recipients, and members of groups underrepresented in mathematics.

 

The 2015 Symposium focused on the areas where dynamical systems theory, spectral theory, and partial differential equations intersect and interact. More information, including a list of contributed speakers and abstracts, registration information, and an archive of the past symposium are contained at the website of the meeting:

 

https://www.ma.utexas.edu/users/tc/TeXAMP/TeXAMP-2015/TeXAMP-2015.html
